H0.text: who is ruling libya. Mustafa Abdul Jalil

H1.text: who is ruling libya. Saif al-Islam Gaddafi

H2.text: who is ruling libya. Abdelhakim Belhaj

H3.text: who is ruling libya. Mohammed Magariaf

A4.text: Fayez Mustafa al‑Sarraj served as the Chairman of the Presidential Council of Libya and head of government of the Government of National Accord

A5.text: Sarraj has been Prime Minister of the Government of National Accord since its installment in December 2015 as part of a United Nations‑led political agreement

A6.text: Belhadj was made commander of the Tripoli Military Council, after the rebels took over Tripoli during Operation Mermaid Dawn in late August 2011.

A7.text: In a 2013 report, Foundation for Defense of Democracies senior fellow Daveed Gartenstein‑Ross reported presumed links between Belhadj and Ansar al‑Sharia, the Tunisian salafi jihadist group.

A8.text: MI6 tipped off the CIA of Belhadj's location before the American-based spy agency captured him and his family and transferred them into Libyan custody.

A9.text: both nations saw Belhadj as a threat to these aspirations.

A10.text: Magariaf resigned in May 2013 in anticipation of the political isolation law which was passed, barring him from office.

A11.text: On 23 October, Jibril resigned as Mustafa Abdul Jalil declared an end to the Libyan civil war, and Abdurrahim El-Keib succeeded him as prime minister on 31 October.

A12.text: The NTC governed Libya for a further ten months after the end of the war, holding elections to a General National Congress on 7 July 2012, and handing power to the newly elected assembly on 8 August.

A13.text: Mustafa Abdul Jalil declared an end to the Libyan civil war.

A14.text: The international community continues to recognise the unity government as the legitimate government of the country.

A15.text: In March 2022, the House of Representatives ceased recognising the Government of National Unity and proclaimed an alternative government, the Government of National Stability (GNS).

A16.text: The NTC's chairman, Mustafa Abdul Jalil, was working to foster good diplomatic relations overseas.

A17.text: On 20 September 2011, the African Union officially recognised the NTC as the legitimate representative of Libya.
